elements.content: Three unusual compounds based on polyoxometalate building blocks, [(C6H5NO2)2Ln(H2O)4]2[IMo6O24][NO3]·4H2O (Ln = Ce 1 and La 2) and [(H2O)4Ag3][Cr(OH)6Mo6O18]·3H2O 3, have been synthesized and characterized by elemental analysis, IR and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, thermogravimetry analysis, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Compounds 1 and 2 are isostructural and possess a unique two-dimensional (2D) network, which is composed of rare earth coordination polymer chains joint together by [IMo6O24]5- polyoxoanions, representing the first example of 2D inorganic−organic hybrid compounds based on A-type Anderson polyoxoanions. Compound 3 is constructed from B-type Anderson polyoxoanions [Cr(OH)6Mo6O18]3- and silver (I) ions to yield a three-dimensional (3D) open framework containing “guest” water molecules. To our best knowledge, it is the first time Anderson-type polyoxometalate motifs have been connected with silver ions to construct a 3D covalent framework.

Compounds 1 and 2 are isostructural and possess a unique two-dimensional (2D) network, which is composed of rare earth coordination polymer chains joint together by [IMo6O24]5- polyoxoanions, representing the first example of 2D inorganic-organic hybrid compounds based on A-type Anderson polyoxoanions. Compound 3 is constructed from B-type Anderson polyoxoanions [Cr(OH)6Mo6O18]3- and silver (I) ions to yield a three-dimensional (3D) open framework containing "guest" water molecules. To our best knowledge, it is the first time Anderson-type polyoxometalate motifs have been connected with silver ions to construct a 3D covalent framework.

elements.content: In this paper, we report three new polyoxometalate-based extended high-dimensional structures with rare earth (Ce and La) ions or silver ions as a linker. Compounds 1 and 2 are isostructural and possess a unique two-dimensional (2D) network, which is composed of rare earth coordination polymer chains and [IMo6O24]5- polyoxoanions as a pillar, representing the first example of 2D inorganic−organic hybrid compounds based on A-type Anderson polyoxoanions. When we change the building block from A-type to B-type Anderson polyoxometalate in the presence of silver ions, compound 3 featuring a three-dimensional open framework was obtained. To our best knowledge, it is the first time Anderson-type POM motifs have been connected with silver ions to construct a 3D covalent framework.

When we change the building block from A-type to B-type Anderson polyoxometalate in the presence of silver ions, compound 3 featuring a three-dimensional open framework was obtained. To our best knowledge, it is the first time Anderson-type POM motifs have been connected with silver ions to construct a 3D covalent framework.

elements.content: Polyoxometalates (POMs), as early transition metal oxide clusters, bear many properties that make them attractive for applications in catalysis, biology, magnetism, optics, and medicine. An intriguing area in this field is the construction of extended high-dimensional solid materials based on POM building blocks and metal cations and/or metal−organic coordination complexes, owing to the remarkable features of metal oxide surfaces and the diversities in the geometric topology. In comparison with a large number of high-dimensional polyoxoanion-based solid materials structurally modified by 3d-block transition metal ions or their complexes, rare earth ions or silver ions as bridging linkers have been paid much less attention in assisting the self-assembly of POM building blocks. This is unexpected for two main reasons:  (i) In most cases, it appears that oxygen atoms on the surface of POMs are rather reactive and are easily combined with the highly oxophilic rare earth ions to form precipitation instead of crystallization. However, the introduction of protecting organic ligands has recently been put forward as one effective method to inhibit the formation of precipitation, because organic ligands can coordinate to rare earth ions and then decrease rare earth ions highly oxophilic properties. (ii) Silver(I) atom is a labile metal center with versatile coordination properties, generally adopting coordination numbers of 2−6 in covalent complexes; therefore, it can become an important choice as bridging linker in designing high-dimensional POM-based compounds. In addition, the probable synergistic effect between silver(I) ions and POMs has been postulated to improve strongly selectivity when they are utilized as the catalysts for selective oxidation by dioxygen compared to the precursor of POMs.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Polyoxometalates (POMs), as early transition metal oxide clusters, bear many properties that make them attractive for applications in catalysis, biology, magnetism, optics, and medicine. An intriguing area in this field is the construction of extended high-dimensional solid materials based on POM building blocks and metal cations and/or metal-organic coordination complexes, owing to the remarkable features of metal oxide surfaces and the diversities in the geometric topology. In comparison with a large number of high-dimensional polyoxoanion-based solid materials structurally modified by 3d-block transition metal ions or their complexes, rare earth ions or silver ions as bridging linkers have been paid much less attention in assisting the self-assembly of POM building blocks. This is unexpected for two main reasons: (i) In most cases, it appears that oxygen atoms on the surface of POMs are rather reactive and are easily combined with the highly oxophilic rare earth ions to form precipitation instead of crystallization. However, the introduction of protecting organic ligands has recently been put forward as one effective method to inhibit the formation of precipitation, because organic ligands can coordinate to rare earth ions and then decrease rare earth ions highly oxophilic properties. (ii) Silver(I) atom is a labile metal center with versatile coordination properties, generally adopting coordination numbers of 2-6 in covalent complexes; therefore, it can become an important choice as bridging linker in designing high-dimensional POM-based compounds. In addition, the probable synergistic effect between silver(I) ions and POMs has been postulated to improve strongly selectivity when they are utilized as the catalysts for selective oxidation by dioxygen compared to the precursor of POMs.

elements.content: On the other hand, several extended high-dimensional structures based on well-defined POMs such as Keggin, Wells−Dawson, and Lindquist type, have been successfully reported up to now. In contrast, using Anderson-type polyoxoanions as inorganic building blocks to construct high-dimensional frameworks remains largely unexplored, although in this type of structure each Mo (or W) atom has two terminal oxygen atoms that make them possess high reactivity and then readily coordinate to other transition metal centers, and they may possess special catalytic and spectroscopic properties. More recently, the successful syntheses of a series of novel two-dimensional (2D) hybrid compounds with a chiral layer structure22 constructed from B-type Anderson polyoxoanions and rare earth-coordination complexes by our groups further inspired our research interest for constructing novel high-dimensional architectures from this kind of polyoxoanion, by replacing the B-type building block with A-type or rare earth ions with other transition metal ions. Taking account of these, our current synthetic strategy is to acquire new extended high-dimensional architectures based on Anderson-type polyoxoanions with rare earth ions or silver(I) ions as linkers.

In contrast, using Anderson-type polyoxoanions as inorganic building blocks to construct high-dimensional frameworks remains largely unexplored, although in this type of structure each Mo (or W) atom has two terminal oxygen atoms that make them possess high reactivity and then readily coordinate to other transition metal centers, and they may possess special catalytic and spectroscopic properties. More recently, the successful syntheses of a series of novel two-dimensional (2D) hybrid compounds with a chiral layer structure22 constructed from B-type Anderson polyoxoanions and rare earth-coordination complexes by our groups further inspired our research interest for constructing novel high-dimensional architectures from this kind of polyoxoanion, by replacing the B-type building block with A-type or rare earth ions with other transition metal ions. Taking account of these, our current synthetic strategy is to acquire new extended high-dimensional architectures based on Anderson-type polyoxoanions with rare earth ions or silver(I) ions as linkers.

elements.content: When an A-type Anderson cluster [IMo6O24]5- was used as the building block, and pyridine-4-carboxylic acid was used as the protecting organic ligand in the presence of rare earth ions (Ce3+ or La3+), two unique compounds were obtained, [(C6H5NO2)2Ln(H2O)4]2[IMo6O24][NO3]·4H2O (Ln = Ce 1 and La 2). When a B-type Anderson cluster [Cr(OH)6Mo6O18]3- was utilized as the structure motif in the presence of silver ions, a structure different from the above two was obtained, [(H2O)4Ag3][Cr(OH)6Mo6O18]·3H2O 3. Compound 1 has a unique 2D network, which is composed of cationic rare earth coordination polymer chains and discrete [IMo6O24]5- polyoxoanions as a pillar, representing the first example of 2D inorganic−organic hybrid compounds constructed from A-type Anderson polyoxoanions. Compound 3 consists of B-type Anderson polyoxoanions and silver ions as a linker, forming a fascinating three-dimensional (3D) open framework with “guest” water molecules residing in the channels. To our best knowledge, it is the first time Anderson-type POM motifs have been connected with silver ions to construct a 3D covalent framework.

When a B-type Anderson cluster [Cr(OH)6Mo6O18]3- was utilized as the structure motif in the presence of silver ions, a structure different from the above two was obtained, [(H2O)4Ag3][Cr(OH)6Mo6O18]⋅3H2O 3. Compound 1 has a unique 2D network, which is composed of cationic rare earth coordination polymer chains and discrete [IMo6O24]5- polyoxoanions as a pillar, representing the first example of 2D inorganic-organic hybrid compounds constructed from A-type Anderson polyoxoanions. Compound 3 consists of B-type Anderson polyoxoanions and silver ions as a linker, forming a fascinating three-dimensional (3D) open framework with "guest" water molecules residing in the channels. To our best knowledge, it is the first time Anderson-type POM motifs have been connected with silver ions to construct a 3D covalent framework.

elements.content: General Considerations. All chemicals were commercially purchased and used without further purification. Na5[IMo6O24]·3H2O23 and Na3[Cr(OH)6Mo6O18]·8H2O24 were synthesized according to the literature and characterized by IR spectroscopy and thermogravimetry (TG) analyses. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 CHN elemental analyzer; I, Cr, Mo, Ce, La and Ag were analyzed on a PLASMA-SPEC(I) ICP atomic emission spectrometer. XPS analyses were performed on a VG ESCALABMKII spectrometer with an Mg Kα (1253.6 eV) achromatic X-ray source. ESR spectrum was recorded on a Japanese JES−FE3AX spectrometer at room temperature. The vacuum inside the analysis chamber was maintained at 6.2 × 10-6 Pa during the analysis. IR spectra were recorded in the range 400−4000 cm-1 on an Alpha Centaurt FT/IR spectrophotometer using KBr pellets. TG analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer TGA7 instrument in flowing N2 with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility data were obtained on a SQUID magnetometer (Quantum Design, MPMS-7) in the temperature range of 2−270 K with an applied field of 1 T. Samples for the magnetic measurements were ground into powder to avoid an effect of the anisotropy.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 General Considerations. All chemicals were commercially purchased and used without further purification. Na5[IMo6O24]⋅3H2O23 and Na3[Cr(OH)6Mo6O18]⋅8H2O24 were synthesized according to the literature and characterized by IR spectroscopy and thermogravimetry (TG) analyses. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 CHN elemental analyzer; I, Cr, Mo, Ce, La and Ag were analyzed on a PLASMA-SPEC(I) ICP atomic emission spectrometer. XPS analyses were performed on a VG ESCALABMKII  spectrometer with an Mg Kα (1253.6 eV) achromatic X-ray source. ESR spectrum was recorded on a Japanese JES-FE3AX spectrometer at room temperature. The vacuum inside the analysis chamber was maintained at 6.2 × 10-6 Pa during the analysis. IR spectra were recorded in the range 400-4000 cm-1 on an Alpha Centaurt FT/IR spectrophotometer using KBr pellets. TG analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer TGA7 instrument in flowing N2 with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility data were obtained on a SQUID magnetometer (Quantum Design, MPMS-7) in the temperature range of 2-270 K with an applied field of 1 T. Samples for the magnetic measurements were ground into powder to avoid an effect of the anisotropy.

elements.content: Synthesis. [(C 6 H 5 NO 2 ) 2 Ln(H 2 O) 4 ] 2 [IMo 6 O 24 ][NO 3 ]·4H 2 O (Ln = Ce 1 and La 2). In a typical synthesis procedure for 1, pyridine-4-carboxylic acid (0.246 g, 2 mmol) and Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (0.434 g, 1 mmol) were dissolved in 20 mL of water. Then 20 mL of water solution of Na5[IMo6O24]·3H2O (1.256 g, 1 mmol) was added. The mixture was refluxed for 2 h at 80 °C and then filtered. The filtrate was kept for one month under ambient conditions, after which time yellow platelet crystals of 1 were isolated in about 25% yield based on Ce. Anal. Calcd for [(C6H5NO2)2Ce(H2O)4]2[IMo6O24][NO3]·4H2O:  I, 5.94; Mo, 26.93; Ce, 13.11; C, 13.49; H, 2.08; N, 3.28 (%). Found:  I, 5.81; Mo, 26.67; Ce, 13.28; C, 13.26; H, 2.32; N, 3.44 (%). FTIR data (cm-1):  3499(s), 3413(s), 3070(m), 2917(w), 2587(w), 2082(w), 1640(m), 1594(vs), 1521(w), 1408(vs), 1248(w), 1201(w), 1154(w), 1084(w), 1058(w), 1010(w), 942(vs), 923(vs), 900(s), 890(s), 855(w), 843(w),772(m), 685(vs), 628(s), 556(s), and 469(s).

elements.content: [(H 2 O) 4 Ag 3 ][Cr(OH) 6 Mo 6 O 18 ] · 3H 2 O (3). AgNO3 (0.170 g, 1 mmol) and aspartic acid (0.113 g, 1 mmol) were dissolved in 20 mL of water. Then 20 mL of water solution of Na3[CrMo6H6O24]·8H2O (1.231 g, 1 mmol) was added. The mixture was heated for 2 h at 80 °C and then filtered. The filtrate was kept for three weeks at ambient conditions, and then purple polycrystals of 3 were isolated in about 18% yield (based on Ag). Diffraction-quality crystals were obtained by recrystallization from 20 mL of hot water. Anal. Calcd for [(H2O)4Ag3][Cr(OH)6Mo6O18]·3H2O:  Cr, 3.54; Mo, 39.22; Ag, 22.05; H, 1.38 (%). Found:  Cr, 3.44; Mo, 39.05; Ag, 22.26; H, 1.59 (%). FTIR data (cm-1):  3205(s), 1621(w), 944(vs), 903(vs), 787(w), 639(vs), 567(m), 526(m), and 415(m).

elements.content: X-ray Crystallography. A yellow single crystal of 1 with dimensions of 0.19 × 0.13 × 0.10 mm was fixed to the end of a glass capillary. The data were collected on a Rigaku R-AXIS RAPID IP diffractometer with Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293 K in the range of 3.04 < θ < 27.48°. Empirical absorption correction was applied. A total of 13 535 (6216 unique, R int = 0.0298) reflections were measured (−12 ≤ h ≤ 13, −13 ≤ k ≤ 13, −18 ≤ l ≤ 18). A colorless single crystal of 2 with dimensions of 0.18 × 0.12 × 0.11 mm was fixed to the end of a glass capillary. The data were collected on a Rigaku R-AXIS RAPID IP diffractometer with Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293 K in the range of 3.04 < θ < 27.48°. Empirical absorption correction was applied. A total of 13 485 (6181 unique, R int = 0.0486) reflections were measured (−13 ≤ h ≤ 13, −13 ≤ k ≤ 13, −18 ≤ l ≤ 18). A purple single crystal of 3 with dimensions of 0.17 × 0.14 × 0.08 mm was fixed to the end of a glass capillary. The data were collected on a Rigaku R-AXIS RAPID IP diffractometer with Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293 K in the range of 3.05 < θ < 27.48°. Empirical absorption correction was applied. A total of 12 905 (6002 unique, R int = 0.0637) reflections were measured (−7 ≤ h ≤ 8, −18 ≤ k ≤ 18, −19 ≤ l ≤ 19).

elements.content: The structures of 1, 2, and 3 were solved by the direct method and refined by the Full-matrix least squares on F 2 using the SHELXTL-97 software. All non-hydrogen atoms in 1, 2, and 3 were refined anisotropically, except N3 in 2. The hydrogen atoms attached to carbon atoms and those to nitrogen atoms of organic ligands were fixed in ideal positions, and those attached to water molecules were not located in 1 and 2. In 3 positions of the hydrogen atoms were not located. A summary of the crystallographic data and structural determination for 1, 2, and 3 is provided in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles with standard deviations in parentheses of 1, 2, and 3 are listed in Table .

Results and Discussion

Syntheses. When we change the basic building block from B-type to A-type Anderson structure with the pyridine-4-carboxylic acid molecule as protecting ligand under the similar reaction conditions with the reported compounds containing a chiral layer structure, two compounds (1 and 2) different from that chiral layer structure were obtained, featuring a 2D inorganic−organic hybrid architecture. This confirms that the POM building blocks perform a very important role in constructing the extended architectures, owing to their possessing different negative charges and different reaction pH values. When silver ions were utilized instead of rare earth ions in the presence of aspartic acid, compound 3 with a 3D open framework was obtained. By plenty of parallel experiments, it was found that the isolation of compound 3 depended on the addition of aspartic acid molecules, although it does not exist in the structure. If no aspartic acid was added to the reaction or it was changed to other amino acids such as glycine and proline, we could not obtain the expected single crystal but only the starting material Na3[Cr(OH)6Mo6O18]·nH2O or powders.

Results and Discussion

 Syntheses. When we change the basic building block from B-type to A-type Anderson structure with the pyridine-4-carboxylic acid molecule as protecting ligand under the similar reaction conditions with the reported compounds containing a chiral layer structure, two compounds (1 and 2) different from that chiral layer structure were obtained, featuring a 2D inorganic-organic hybrid architecture. This confirms that the POM building blocks perform a very important role in constructing the extended architectures, owing to their possessing different negative charges and different reaction pH values. When silver ions were utilized instead of rare earth ions in the presence of aspartic acid, compound 3 with a 3D open framework was obtained. By plenty of parallel experiments, it was found that the isolation of compound 3 depended on the addition of aspartic acid molecules, although it does not exist in the structure. If no aspartic acid was added to the reaction or it was changed to other amino acids such as glycine and proline, we could not obtain the expected single crystal but only the starting material Na3[Cr(OH)6Mo6O18]⋅nH2O or powders.

elements.content: Structural Analysis of 1 and 2. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses reveal that compounds 1 and 2 are isostructural, and the unit cell dimensions, volumes, related bond distances and angles are only slightly changed as a consequence of lanthanide shrinking. The structures of the two composite compounds exhibit an unusual 2D layer framework composed of [IMo6O24]5- polyoxoanion clusters, Ln-pyridine-4-carboxylic acid coordination complexes (Ln = Ce 1 and La 2), and lattice water molecules. The [IMo6O24]5- cluster has an A-type Anderson structure, which consists of seven edge-sharing octahedra, six of which are {MoO6} octahedra arranged hexagonally around the central {IO6} octahedron (see Figure ). Four kinds of oxygen atoms exist in the cluster according to the way the oxygen atoms are coordinated:  terminal oxygen Ot, terminal oxygen Ot‘ linked to Ln3+, double-bridging oxygen Ob, central oxygen Oc. Thus, the Mo−O bond lengths can be grouped into four classes:  Mo−Ot 1.685(3)−1.706(3) Å, Mo−Ot‘ 1.732(3) Å, Mo−Ob 1.905(3)−1.940(3) Å, Mo−Oc 2.311(3)−2.372(3) Å in 1, and Mo−Ot 1.687(4)−1.709(3) Å, Mo−Ot‘ 1.733(3) Å, Mo−Ob 1.900(4)−1.941(4) Å, Mo−Oc 2.301(3)−2.364(4) Å in 2. The central I−Oc distances vary from 1.881(3) to 1.894(3) Å in 1, and from 1.879(3) to 1.890(3) in 2. The bond angle of O−I−Ocis ranges from 86.56(1) to 93.44(1) ° in 1, and from 86.49(2) to 93.51(2) in 2, and the bond angle of O−I−Otrans is 180.0°.

elements.content: There is only one crystallographically independent Ln(III) (Ln = Ce and La), residing in the center of a distorted monocapped square antiprism, which is defined by one terminal oxygen atom from one [IMo6O24]5- unit, four carboxyl oxygen atoms from two pyridine-4-carboxylic acid molecules, and four water molecules. The average Ce−O bond length is 2.540 Å in 1, and La−O 2.557 Å in 2. These coordination patterns cause the Mo−Ot‘ distances to be slightly longer than the unshared Mo−Ot bond lengths. Each of two crystallographically independent pyridine-4-carboxylic acid molecules acts as a bidentate ligand by utilizing its carboxyl oxygen atoms coordinating to two adjacent Ln(III) atoms.

The average Ce-O bond length is 2.540 Å in 1, and La-O 2.557 Å in 2. These coordination patterns cause the Mo-Ot‘ distances to be slightly longer than the unshared Mo-Ot bond lengths. elements.content: In the structure, neighboring Ln(III) atoms are linked together by pyridine-4-carboxylic acid ligands to form a cationic one-dimensional (1D) polymer chain (shown in Figure ). Then each chain is connected to two other parallel chains through [IMo6O24]5- subunits in the bc-plane. In a word, the cationic 1D chains are pillared by the [IMo6O24]5- subunits to form a 2D sheet (see Figure ). Such connectivity results in a small cavity. This type of layer packing along the b-axis leads to a supramolecular channel framework where water molecules are located (Figure S1, Supporting Information). Extensive hydrogen-bonding interactions exist among free water molecules, polyoxoanions, ligands, and water molecules coordinated to the Ln3+ (Table S1, Supporting Information). It is believed that the extensive hydrogen-bonding interactions play an important role in stabilizing the 3D supramolecular framework. To our best knowledge, compound 1 represents the first example of 2D inorganic−organic hybrid architectures based on A-type Anderson polyoxoanions.

elements.content: Structural Analysis of 3. Single-crystal X-ray structural analysis reveals that the structure of 3 is a unique 3D open framework constructed from [Cr(OH)6Mo6O18]3- building blocks and Ag+ cations, with lattice water molecules residing in the channels. The [Cr(OH)6Mo6O18]3- cluster has a B-type Anderson structure, which is made of seven edge-sharing octahedra, six of which are {MoO6} octahedra arranged hexagonally around the central {Cr(OH)6}octahedron (see Figure ). Five kinds of oxygen atoms exist in the cluster according to the way the oxygen atoms are coordinated:  terminal oxygen Ot, terminal oxygen Ot‘ linked to Ag+, double-bridging oxygen Ob, double-bridging oxygen Ob‘ linked to Ag+, central oxygen Oc. Thus, the Mo−O distances can be grouped into five sets: Mo−Ot 1.694(8)−1.716(8) Å, Mo−Ot‘ 1.692(7)−1.722(7) Å, Mo−Ob 1.915(7)−1.977(8) Å, Mo−Ob‘ 1.919(7)−1.954(7) Å, Mo−Oc 2.255(7)−2.328(7) Å in 3. The central Cr−Oc distances vary from 1.951(7) to 1.980(7) Å. The bond angle of O−Cr−Ocis ranges from 83.8(3) to 95.9(3) °, and O−Cr−Otrans ranges from 179.1(3) to 179.7(3)° in 3.

elements.content: There are three crystallization-independent silver atoms in 3. Both Ag(1) and Ag(3) are six-coordinate, defined by four terminal oxygen atoms from three {MoO6} octahedra of different polyoxoanions (Ag(1)−O = 2.377(7), 2.539(8), 2.543(8), and 2.592(8); Ag(3)−O = 2.399(8), 2.427(9), 2.504(8), and 2.537(8) Å), one double-bridging oxygen atom (Ag(1)−O = 2.418(7), Ag(3)−O = 2.430(7) Å), and one water molecule (Ag(1)−OH2 = 2.344(9), Ag(3)−OH2 = 2.422(9) Å). Ag(2) is five-coordinate, coordinated by two terminal oxygen atoms from one {MoO6} octahedra (Ag(2)−O = 2.465(8) and 2.624(5) Å), one double-bridging oxygen atom (Ag(2)−O = 2.563(6) Å), and two water molecules (Ag(2)−OH2 = 2.424(9) and 2.348(11) Å). The average bond distance is 2.469 Å for Ag(1)−O, 2.485 Å for Ag(2)−O and 2.453 Å for Ag(3)−O.

elements.content: In the structure, each Anderson anion [Cr(OH)6Mo6O18]3- acts as a hendeca-dentate chelating ligand, coordinating to silver ions via terminal oxygen atoms and bridging oxygen atoms (see Figure S3, Supporting Information). To our knowledge, the coordination mode has not been observed in other Anderson-type POMs compounds. As shown in Figure , first these [Cr(OH)6Mo6O18]3- clusters are linked by some Ag+ ions to form a 1D chain, and then each chain is connected to two other parallel chains through Ag−O−Mo bonds to yield a window-like 2D layer. The 2D layer structure built up of polyoxoanions and silver ions is rare. Furthermore, these 2D sheets are connected by other five-coordinated Ag+ ions to form a 3D open framework (Figure ). It is notable that this kind of connection mode results in the formation of an intersecting channel, which was occupied by dissociated lattice water molecules. The dimensions of the channel are ca. 7.3 × 4.5 Å along the a-axis (shown in Figure S4, Supporting Information). Compound 3 represents the first example of a 3D covalent framework containing Anderson-type polyoxometalates and silver ions.

elements.content: The bond valence sum calculations27 indicate that I site is in the +7 oxidation state, Ce and La sites are in the +3 oxidation state, and all Mo sites are in the +6 oxidation state in compounds 1 and 2. Cr site is in the +3 oxidation state, Ag site is in the +1 oxidation state, and all Mo sites are in the +6 oxidation in compound 3.

elements.content: XPS Spectroscopy. The XPS spectra of compound 1 in the energy regions of Mo3d, Ce3d, and I3d show peaks at 232.2, 833.2, 624.5 eV, respectively, attributable to Mo6+, Ce3+, and I7+. The XPS spectra of compound 2 in the energy regions of Mo3d, La3d, and I3d show peaks at 232.4, 835.8, 624.8 eV, respectively, attributable to Mo6+, La3+, and I7+. The XPS spectra of compound 3 in the energy regions of Mo3d and Ag3d show peaks at 232.3 and 368.1 eV, respectively, attributable to Mo6+ and Ag+. These results further confirm the composition of compounds 1, 2, and 3 (see Figure S5a−c, Supporting Information).

elements.content: ESR Spectroscopy. ESR studies have been undertaken to elucidate the electronic properties of the Cr3+ in compound 3. The ESR spectrum of compound 3 was recorded at room temperature on polycrystalline powder sample (shown in Figure S6, Supporting Information). The effective g values g ≈ 2.06, 3.11, and 4.45 are typical of an electronic spin S = 3/2 (Cr3+) with moderately large zero field splitting and small rhombicity. These spectral features compare well with that reported in the literature for the Cr3+ spin systems. A broad, featureless high-field tail with magnetic field corresponding to g < 2 was also discovered.

A broad, featureless high-field tail with magnetic field corresponding to g < 2 was also discovered.

elements.content: FT-IR Spectroscopy. In the IR spectrum of compound 1, the features at 3499, 3413, 3070, 1640, 1594, 1521, 1408, 1248, and 1201 cm-1 can be regarded as characteristics of the pyridine-4-carboxylic acid molecule. The peaks at 942, 923, 900, 890, 772, 685, 628, 556, and 469 cm-1 are attributed to ν(Mo−Ot), ν(I−O), ν(Mo−Ob), and ν(Mo−Oc) of the [IMo6O24]5- polyoxoanion. The IR spectrum of compound 2 is similar to that of 1 (see Figure S7a,b, Supporting Information). In the IR spectrum of compound 3, the characteristic peaks at 944, 903, 787, 639, 567, 526, and 415 cm-1 are attributed to the [Cr(OH)6Mo6O18]3- polyoxoanion (Figure S7c, Supporting Information).

elements.content: TG Analyses. The TG curve of 1 is shown in Figure S8a, Supporting Information. It shows a total weight loss of 43.10% in the range of 44−590 °C, which agrees with the calculated value of 44.22%. The weight loss of 9.62% at 44−180 °C corresponds to the loss of all noncoordinated and coordinated water molecules (calc. 10.11%). The weight loss of 33.48% at 191−590 °C arises from the decomposition of NO3 - anions, pyridine-4-carboxylic acid molecules, iodine molecules, and partial oxygen molecules (calc. 34.11%).

elements.content: Magnetic Properties of Compound 1. The magnetic susceptibilities of 1 were investigated from 270 to 2 K at 1 T on the polycrystalline power samples (see Figure ). The temperature dependence of 1/χM for 1 deviates the Curie−Weiss law in the temperature range, which is probably due to spin−orbit interactions. The magnetic behavior of compound 1 is similar to that of the simple Ce(III) ions complexes. Further magnetic investigation in this system is underway.

elements.content: In conclusion, the success in synthesizing compounds 1, 2, and 3 provides novel examples of the utilities of presynthesized Anderson clusters as building unit, and rare earth or silver ions as a bridge for constructing high-dimensional solid-state materials. The structures of 1 and 2 possess a 2D inorganic−organic hybrid sheet composed of rare earth-organic polymer chains and A-type Anderson polyoxoanions [IMo6O24]5- as a pillar. Compound 3 featuring a 3D open framework was obtained when we change the building block from A-type Anderson in 1 to B-type Anderson in 3 in the presence of silver ions as inorganic linker and aspartic acid molecules. The obvious structure differences of compounds 1 (2) and 3 further confirm that the POM building blocks and bridging metal ions perform very important roles in constructing extended architectures, owing to the different negative charges and different reaction pH values of POMs, and the different coordination modes of metal ions. This approach is expected to be effective for the further construction of novel high-dimensional POM frameworks, and more investigations are ongoing.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, the success in synthesizing compounds 1, 2, and 3 provides novel examples of the utilities of presynthesized Anderson clusters as building unit, and rare earth or silver ions as a bridge for constructing high-dimensional solid-state materials. The structures of 1 and 2 possess a 2D inorganic-organic hybrid sheet composed of rare earth-organic polymer chains and A-type Anderson polyoxoanions [IMo6O24]5- as a pillar. Compound 3 featuring a 3D open framework was obtained when we change the building block from A-type Anderson in 1 to B-type Anderson in 3 in the presence of silver ions as inorganic linker and aspartic acid molecules. The obvious structure differences of compounds 1 (2) and 3 further confirm that the POM building blocks and bridging metal ions perform very important roles in constructing extended architectures, owing to the different negative charges and different reaction pH values of POMs, and the different coordination modes of metal ions. This approach is expected to be effective for the further construction of novel high-dimensional POM frameworks, and more investigations are ongoing.

Synthesis. [(C 6 H 5 NO 2 ) 2 Ln(H 2 O) 4 ] 2 [IMo 6 O 24 ][NO 3 ]·4H 2 O (Ln = Ce 1 and La 2). In a typical synthesis procedure for 1, pyridine-4-carboxylic acid (0.246 g, 2 mmol) and Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (0.434 g, 1 mmol) were dissolved in 20 mL of water. Then 20 mL of water solution of Na5[IMo6O24]·3H2O (1.256 g, 1 mmol) was added. The mixture was refluxed for 2 h at 80 °C and then filtered. The filtrate was kept for one month under ambient conditions, after which time yellow platelet crystals of 1 were isolated in about 25% yield based on Ce. Anal. Calcd for [(C6H5NO2)2Ce(H2O)4]2[IMo6O24][NO3]·4H2O:  I, 5.94; Mo, 26.93; Ce, 13.11; C, 13.49; H, 2.08; N, 3.28 (%). Found:  I, 5.81; Mo, 26.67; Ce, 13.28; C, 13.26; H, 2.32; N, 3.44 (%). cln_elements.content:
TG Analyses. The TG curve of 1 is shown in Figure S8a, Supporting Information. It shows a total weight loss of 43.10% in the range of 44−590 °C, which agrees with the calculated value of 44.22%. The weight loss of 9.62% at 44−180 °C corresponds to the loss of all noncoordinated and coordinated water molecules (calc. 10.11%). The weight loss of 33.48% at 191−590 °C arises from the decomposition of NO3 - anions, pyridine-4-carboxylic acid molecules, iodine molecules, and partial oxygen molecules (calc. 34.11%).

The TG curves of compound 2 in the range of 50−592 °C exhibit weight loss stages similar to those observed for compound 1 (see Figure S8b, Supporting Information). The overall weight losses (45.09%) are in agreement with the calculated values (44.25%), considering the loss of all water molecules, and the decomposition of NO3 - anions, pyridine-4-carboxylic acid molecules, iodine molecules, and partial oxygen molecules.

The TG curve of 3 is shown in Figure S8c, Supporting Information. The TG curve gives a total weight loss of 11.35% in the range of 35−415 °C, which agrees with the calculated value of 12.27%, corresponding to the loss of all noncoordinated water, coordinated water, and constitutional water molecules.
